content.T_0000: Heterogeneous Single-Atom Catalyst for Visible-Light-Driven High-Turnover $\mathbf { C O } _ { 2 }$ Reduction: The Role of Electron Transfer

content.C_0000: Chao Gao, Shuangming Chen, Ying Wang, Jiawen Wang, Xusheng Zheng, Junfa Zhu, Li Song,* Wenkai Zhang, and Yujie Xiong*

content.C_0001: Visible-light-driven conversion of $\mathbf { C O } _ { 2 }$ into chemical fuels is an intriguing approach to address the energy and environmental challenges.

content.C_0002: In principle, light harvesting and catalytic reactions can be both optimized by combining the merits of homogeneous and heterogeneous photocatalysts; however, the efficiency of charge transfer between light absorbers and catalytic sites is often too low to limit the overall photocatalytic performance.

content.C_0003: In this communication, it is reported that the single-atom Co sites coordinated on the partially oxidized graphene nanosheets can serve as a highly active and durable heterogeneous catalyst for $\mathbf { C O } _ { 2 }$ conversion, wherein the graphene bridges homogeneous light absorbers with single-atom catalytic sites for the efficient transfer of photoexcited electrons.

content.C_0004: As a result, the turnover number for CO production reaches a high value of 678 with an unprecedented turnover frequency of $3 . 7 7 \mathrm { \ m i n ^ { - 1 } }$ , superior to those obtained with the state-of-theart heterogeneous photocatalysts.

content.C_0005: This work provides fresh insights into the design of catalytic sites toward photocatalytic $\mathbf { C O } _ { 2 }$ conversion from the angle of single-atom catalysis and highlights the role of charge kinetics in bridging the gap between heterogeneous and homogeneous photocatalysts.

content.C_0006: Artificial photosynthesis is an intriguing approach to solar-tochemical energy conversion, wherein solar energy is stored in chemical bonds as solar fuels.[1]

content.C_0007: In particular, the solar-driven conversion of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ into energy-rich chemical fuels has attracted tremendous attention, considering its double benefits for enriching energy supply and mitigating $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ pollution.[2] As

content.C_0019: traditionally classified into the two categories of catalysts that have been developed for photocatalytic $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ conversion, the homogeneous and heterogeneous photocatalysts distinctly exhibit their own strengths and weaknesses.[3]

content.C_0020: Homogeneous photocatalysts are known for their tunable light absorption with large coefficients as well as high activity and/or selectivity, benefiting from the atomically dispersed catalytic sites and versatile coordination forms.[4]

content.C_0021: However, homogeneous catalysts commonly suffer from the relatively costly and timeconsuming synthesis as well as the difficult extraction and recycling for long-term use, which severely impedes their practical industrial applications.[5]

content.C_0022: In comparison, heterogeneous catalysts can largely overcome these limitations but their photocatalytic performance is yet to be improved.

content.C_0023: For this reason, it is an ideal solution toward the sustainable development of photocatalysis that the merits of both homogeneous and

content.C_0025: As commonly recognized in previous attempts, this strategy has been proven as an extremely challenging task.

content.C_0026: To combine the homogeneous and heterogeneous photocatalysis, we have to specifically address the three key steps in photocatalysis—light absorption, charge separation and transfer, and catalytic reactions.

content.C_0027: In terms of catalytic reactions, the heterogeneous single-atom catalysts that were first demonstrated in 2011[6] have recently sparked tremendous interest in various catalytic reactions[7] as they can bridge the gap between heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis.

content.C_0028: In the single-atom catalysts, the individual and isolated metal atoms anchored on supports can be regarded as homogeneous catalyst analogs when the supports serve as rigid ligands from the viewpoint of coordination chemistry.[3b]

content.C_0029: This similarity offers the following advantages as compared with their nanocluster, nanoparticle, and bulk counterparts: (i) an unexpectedly high activity and selectivity by their unsaturated coordination sites and tunable electronic structures; (ii) a significant reduction in catalytic metal usage by maximizing the number of catalytic sites; and (iii) well-defined active sites for mechanistic studies.

content.C_0030: Previous studies on heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts have suggested that earth-abundant Co is a promising catalytic

content.C_0031: center for $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ reduction;[4e,8] however, the reported turnover numbers (TONs) and turnover frequencies (TOFs) for heterogeneous Co photocatalysts (e.g., metal-organic frameworks[7h]) are still behind the records by homogeneous Co catalysts.

content.C_0032: For this reason, we aim to tackle the limitations of traditionally catalysts for photocatalytic $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ reduction based on single-atom Co catalysts.

content.C_0033: As a proof of concept, we employ a typical homogeneous photosensitizer $[ \mathrm { R u ( b p y ) } _ { 3 } ] \mathrm { C l } _ { 2 }$ as the light absorber, as it can offer a large absorption coefficient for visible light.

content.C_0034: To fully exploit the activity of single-atom Co sites for photocatalytic $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ reduction, two key factors should be considered—the transfer of photoexcited electrons from light absorbers to catalytic Co sites that modulates the efficiency of entire photocatalytic system[3d] and the metal–support interactions that stabilize single metal atoms as well as alter their charge states.[9]

content.C_0035: Thus, the supports that bridge catalytic sites and light absorbers hold the key to achieving high photocatalytic performance.

content.C_0036: An ideal support should possess the following features: (i) specific anchoring sites to tightly “grasp” the single atoms; (ii) large surface area and flexible surface to allow the high loading of catalytic sites; and (iii) high carrier mobility to facilitate the photoexcited electron transfer.

content.C_0037: In this communication, we demonstrate a simple thermal treatment approach to stably immobilize the isolated single Co atoms on the partially oxidized graphene nanosheets $( \mathsf { C o } _ { 1 } \mathrm { - } \mathsf { G } )$ for photocatalytic $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ conversion.

content.C_0038: In our approach, the partially oxidized graphene plays dual roles in photocatalysis—offering C/O functional groups as a rigid ligand to anchor Co atoms and possessing relatively high conductivity to facilitate the transfer of photoexcited electrons from $[ \mathrm { R u ( b p y ) } _ { 3 } ] \mathrm { C l } _ { 2 }$ light absorber to catalytic Co sites, which well meets the criteria for supports above.

content.C_0039: With $[ \mathrm { R u ( b p y ) } _ { 3 } ] \mathrm { C l } _ { 2 }$ as a visible-light absorber, the efficient electron transfer enables the high-turnover photocatalytic $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ reduction at the single-atom Co sites, which reaches an unprecedented TOF (up to $3 . 7 7 \mathrm { ~ m i n ^ { - 1 } }$ ) for heterogeneous catalyst.

content.C_0040: This work provides a promising approach to engineering the actives sites for solar-driven $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ conversion and highlights the key role of charge kinetics in photocatalysis at the intersection of homogeneous and heterogeneous systems.

content.C_0169: As shown in Figure S14 (Supporting Information), the $\mathrm { g { - } C _ { 3 } N _ { 4 } @ C o _ { 1 } { - } G }$ system can achieve effective and sustainable $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ reduction under visible irradiation.

content.C_0170: Overall, our designed $\mathrm { C o } _ { 1 } – \mathrm { G }$ nanosheets play dual important roles in the photocatalytic system: (i) hosting the single-atom Co sites for catalytic $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ reduction; and (ii) accepting electrons from the light absorber and facilitating the transfer of the received electrons to catalytic sites toward $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ reduction.

content.C_0171: In summary, we have developed a highly efficient photocatalytic system for $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ reduction by bridging the heterogeneous single-atom Co catalyst with homogeneous light absorber $[ \mathrm { R u ( b p y ) } _ { 3 } ] \mathrm { C l } _ { 2 }$ through graphene.

content.C_0172: The developed heterogeneous single-atom catalysts well bridge the gap between heterogeneous and homogeneous photocatalysts, and thus combines their merits of high activity and robustness.

content.C_0173: As a result, the isolated Co atoms coordinated with graphene can serve as a highly active and sustainable catalyst for $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ conversion with outstanding TON and TOF.

content.C_0174: The demonstrated roles of graphene in metal– support interactions and electron transfer highlight the importance of charge kinetics to photocatalysis, particularly when the heterogeneous and homogeneous photocatalysts are bridged.

content.C_0175: This work not only puts forward a promising strategy for developing high-performance heterogeneous photocatalysts by engineering single-atom catalytic sites, but also provides insights into charge kinetics toward efficient photocatalytic $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ reduction.

content.C_0176: Synthesis of $\mathsf { C o } _ { 1 } \mathrm { - } \mathsf { G }$ Nanosheets: An aqueous suspension of graphene oxide (GO, $2 { \mathrm { ~ m g ~ m L ^ { - 1 } } }$ ) was first sonicated for $3 \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$ .

content.C_0177: Subsequently $5 0 ~ \mu \ L$ of aqueous ${ \mathsf { C o C l } } _ { 2 } { \cdot } 6 { \mathsf { H } } _ { 2 } { \mathsf { O } }$ solution $( 3 \mathrm { \ m g \ m L ^ { - 1 } } )$ was added to $2 . 5 \ \mathsf { m L }$ of GO suspension, followed by sonication for 15 min and shaking for 15 min (Step 1).

content.C_0178: The precursor solution was then freeze-dried to yield a brown sample (Step 2).

content.C_0179: The obtained sample was annealed at $5 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ for 3 h under Ar protection (Step 3), which converted the GO into reduced graphene oxide (namely, $\mathsf { C o } _ { 1 } \mathrm { - } \mathsf { C } )$ .
